utterances: Talking about nanotechnology with Jeremy Levy on Talk of the Nation: Science Friday from NPR News.

You know, you talk about an electronic probe, a microscope, for some of the folks - Bunny on tweet - our Twitters are coming in and saying, you know, it sounds what you're doing more like a plotter, you know?
You draw an architecture, and its goes out and plots, you know, a whole big design on the surface.
It's very much like that, of course, but smaller.
Yeah.
And yeah.
So, basically, we can use, actually, the same kinds of plotting packages that are used for much bigger circuits, but we use them with our microscope.
And can you - and you can make - can you make a circuit like that by just plotting it?
Yes, and that's literally what we do.
And when we made the transistor, we sort of consciously tried to make something that was as simple as possible, three lines.
It's hard to imagine something that's simpler than that and yet acts as a transistor.
Is this very expensive, this stuff?
Very expensive?
Well...
To make?
The - I mean, the costs are - it's hard to compare it, for example, with a chip that is the result of 50 years of technological innovation.
Right.

But let's say, the substrates, the - that - so, the sort of big part of the material that (unintelligible) is - can be actually pretty expensive, but it may be possible to grow those materials on silicon.

So, actually, one of the things that we may be trying to do research on in the future is to see whether we can integrate this capability, these oxide hetero structures on silicon and put them on big silicon wafers, and that would make them a lot more cost-effective.
Mm-hmm.
So, you'd create sort of as hybrid?
Exactly.
Yeah.
As you say, one of the big challenges is you have this tiny thing, how do you put the leads on it to get the stuff in and out?
Precisely.
Yeah.
The wires are much bigger than what you're drawing.
Yes, that's true.
And we do - but we do have the top side and the bottom side and...
(Soundbite of laughter)
To work with.
Manic Depression is searching my soul.
Yeah, I sort of have some pictures up - yeah, I have a Web site, epsilon.phyast.pitt.edu.
All right, well, we'll melt it down for you this afternoon when everybody goes to look at it.
OK.
So, be ready for that.
I want to thank you for taking time to be with us, Jeremy.
Well, thank you, Ira.
And keep us abreast of any kind of new developments that you have, and we'll be happy to talk about where you go from here.
Wonderful.
You're welcome.
Jeremy Levy is a professor of physics and astronomy at the University of Pittsburgh in Pennsylvania, and he was talking about his Etch-A-Sketch ideas for making nanotransistors.
That's about all the time we have for today.
Our program is produced by Christopher Intagliata and senior producer Annette Heist.
Charles Bergquist is our director, and Flora Lichtman is our producer for digital media.
Our intern is Shelly DuBois.
Neal Rausch is our technical director and at the controls here today is Manya.
We also had help in Second Life from Lynn Cullins, Dave Andrews, Jeff Corbin and the University of Denver.

If you missed any of the stuff we talked about today, you might have a little trouble hearing some of the program today, we're going to have it up there on our Web - we apologize for that, some technical difficulties we had at the beginning of the program.
We apologize, but our podcast will be up there.
Hopefully, the whole thing will be ready and we can listen to it once we get it digitized.
Also surf over to our Web site at ScienceFriday.com.
We are Twittering, @SciFri is tweet address, and also we're podcasting, and folks in Second Life are gathering around as they do every Friday afternoon.
I'm Ira Flatow in New York.
Back now with your lead story.
President Bush in Baghdad, he's met with Iraq's Prime Minister, Nouri al-Malaki.
The President's trip comes as U.S.
and mostly Iraqi forces are preparing for what is supposed to be a very large security crackdown in Baghdad.
It's going to start tomorrow.
It's supposed to involve 70,000 troops, making it the largest military operation since the U.S.
handed authority over to Iraqis two years ago.
Dexter Filkins is a Baghdad correspondent for the New York Times.
He joins us now.
Dexter, what is the mission here?
There's so - there's so many tasks that need to be accomplished to bring this capital city of about four million people under control that it's kind of difficult to say where to start.
But they have to stop the anarchy.
And what I mean is, it used to be you could say they have to fight the insurgency, and then more recently it's been they've got to stop the sectarian killings.
Now it's everything.
I mean now it's the insurgency, it's sectarian killings, it's crime.
Crime is unbelievable here.
Violent kidnapping.
Every neighborhood in Baghdad now has a level of crime and violence in it which is really unimaginable.
I mean there's something like 40 or 50 kidnappings a day just in Baghdad, from what we here.
And these aren't political kidnappings.
These are ransom, you know, I'm going to make a buck by kidnapping somebody.
Well, the line where political and criminal begins is a pretty hard one to draw.

I mean a lot of these guys are kind of - work in both sides, and they use things like kidnapping to finance their other activities, whether that's killing Iraqi soldiers or police or American soldiers or whatever.
But there's a lot of overlap there.
Is this going to be a U.S.
or an Iraqi-led operation, do you know?
Well, you can be sure of two things.
One, the bulk of the troops will be Iraqi, probably Iraqi army and Iraqi police.
The second thing is that the Americans will be intimately involved in trying to direct it and trying to advise how things go.
I should just say that I'm a little skeptical, having witnessed some of these operations before that the Iraqi government has announced.

You know, there was operation lightning, you know, about a year ago, and they said we're going to, we're going to have troops all over the streets and we're going to lock down everybody, we're going to stop the insurgency, it was the insurgency then.
And it wasn't all that evident.
I mean you think you're going to wake up in the morning and there's going to be a roadblock on every street, and there's not.

And so I'll certainly be pleasantly surprised if it's evident that there's a lot more police and troops on the streets, but you know, in order for them to do that, they're going to have to take them from somewhere else, and I don't know how they're going to quite pull that off.
You've been writing recently about the Iraqi security forces and the various problems, infiltrations by militias and questions of trust of these forces.
In your view are they ready for an operation like this?
It depends on what you ask them to do.

What we've seen here in the past several months is you have the police department, which in Iraq is 130,000 now, I think, they're approaching - police and what they call special police, which are kind of paramilitary guys.
That's mostly a Shiite force.

Over the past six, eight months, really over the past year, there's been a lot of really hardcore operations by these guys in which it's pretty clear a lot of civilians, Sunni civilians, predominantly in Sunni neighborhoods, have been killed, kidnapped, tortured, disappeared, put in jails that nobody knows about and forgotten about.
That they can do.
I mean I think the question is, is whether they can do it in a disciplined way and in a precise way, where they don't end up alienating, you know, half the population.
One last question here, and this is back to the President's visit.
I read in a wire account that Prime Minister al-Malaki only knew five minutes before the meeting that Mr. Bush was going to come.
He had gone to the U.S.
Embassy supposedly to partake in this video conference that was going to send his signal back to Camp David where the president was supposedly holding a meeting.
And he was going to participate in it.
How does that sound to you?
It sounds kind of strange.
It must have been quite a surprise to the Prime Minster.
It must've been quite a surprise, but, I mean, I have to say it doesn't surprise me at all.

Even if you're inside the Green Zone, which is supposed to be safe - I mean we live outside the Green Zone, but even if you're inside the Green Zone, you don't really know who's infiltrated what security force.
You don't know who's gotten a car in there with a bomb.
So there's so much concern that the security forces here are infiltrated by people who might do something really, really bad that they just decided to surprised everybody.
And Robert Blendon at Harvard's T.H.
Chan School of Public Health says that of 1,300 rural adults surveyed by NPR, 58 percent said their towns need outside help.
I think that's a surprise for a lot of people, that there is a willingness by most - not all - to reach out for outside help.
Take the proud little town of Belle in central Missouri.
There's a big struggle going on in this small town (laughter) right now.

Kathy Stanfield, a feisty, compact woman pushing 70, looks up from her front porch at a town of 1,500 corralled by green rolling hills and farm fields and split by opposing views of outside involvement.
People wanting it to grow and wanting it to be the best it can be and people that would prefer that everyone back off and let them do what they want.
It's pressing here because this town is struggling with the same issues plaguing much of rural America.
Money - you don't have a tax base anymore that you used to have.
